verses.text: At the end of every seven years, you shall grant a release.
verses.comment: References the seven-year cycle for debt release, see also Sabbath year regulations.

verses.text: And this is the manner of the release: every creditor shall release what he has lent to his neighbor. He shall not require it from his neighbor or his brother, because the Lord’s release has been proclaimed.
verses.comment: The original Hebrew emphasizes 'neighbor' and 'brother' as fellow Israelites.

verses.text: You may require it from a foreigner, but you shall release whatever is yours with your brother.
verses.comment: Clear differentiation between Israelites ('brother') and non-Israelites ('foreigner').

verses.text: But there shall be no poor among you; for the Lord will greatly bless you in the land which the Lord your God is giving you to possess as your inheritance,
verses.comment: This refers to an ideal, conditional upon obedience—poverty is mitigated by God’s blessing.

verses.text: if only you carefully obey the voice of the Lord your God, being careful to do all this commandment which I command you today.
verses.comment: Blessing is conditional upon obedience.

verses.text: For the Lord your God will bless you, as he promised you, and you shall lend to many nations, but you shall not borrow; and you shall rule over many nations, but they shall not rule over you.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the terms of Israel's sovereignty and prosperity.

verses.text: If there is a poor man among you, one of your brothers within any of your towns in your land which the Lord your God is giving you, you shall not harden your heart or shut your hand against your poor brother;
verses.comment: The Hebrew idiom 'harden your heart' is preserved in modern language.

verses.text: but you shall open your hand to him and willingly lend him enough for his need, whatever he lacks.
verses.comment: The expression 'open your hand' is kept close to the Hebrew.

verses.text: Be careful lest there be a wicked thought in your heart, saying, ‘The seventh year, the year of release, is near,’ and your eye be evil against your poor brother and you give him nothing; and he cry to the Lord against you, and you be guilty of sin.
verses.comment: ‘Evil eye’ is retained as a Hebrew idiom for stinginess.

verses.text: You shall surely give to him, and your heart shall not be grieved when you give to him, because for this the Lord your God will bless you in all your work and in all that you undertake.
verses.comment: The translation keeps the emphatic 'surely give' as in Hebrew.

verses.text: For there will never cease to be poor in the land. Therefore I command you, saying, ‘You shall open your hand wide to your brother, to your needy and to your poor, in your land.’
verses.comment: The tension between verse 4 and this verse is preserved—ideal vs. reality.

verses.text: If your brother, a Hebrew man or a Hebrew woman, is sold to you and serves you six years, then in the seventh year you shall let him go free from you.
verses.comment: Both male and female servants are noted per Hebrew text.

verses.text: And when you let him go free from you, you shall not let him go empty-handed.
verses.comment: Parallels the Exodus—release from Egypt.

verses.text: You shall generously supply him from your flock, your threshing floor, and your winepress. As the Lord your God has blessed you, you shall give to him.
verses.comment: The three sources are specified, as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And you shall remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt, and the Lord your God redeemed you; therefore I command you this thing today.
verses.comment: Redemption from Egypt is the basis for compassion.

verses.text: But if he says to you, ‘I will not leave you,’ because he loves you and your household, since he is well with you,
verses.comment: The voluntary choice of the servant is original language.

verses.text: then you shall take an awl and thrust it through his ear into the door, and he shall be your servant forever. Also for your female servant you shall do the same.
verses.comment: Keeping references to bondservant and ear-piercing, as in the Hebrew law.

verses.text: It shall not seem hard to you when you let him go free from you; for he has served you six years for twice the value of a hired worker, and the Lord your God will bless you in all that you do.
verses.comment: 'Twice the value of a hired worker' translates the original idiom.

verses.text: All the firstborn males that are born of your herd and your flock you shall set apart to the Lord your God. You shall not work with the firstborn of your herd, nor shear the firstborn of your flock.
verses.comment: Firstborn animals are dedicated, with work and shearing forbidden.

verses.text: You and your household shall eat it before the Lord your God year by year in the place which the Lord chooses.
verses.comment: Annual consumption before God at the chosen place; instructions parallel firstborn regulations.

verses.text: But if it has any defect—if it is lame or blind, or has any serious blemish—you shall not sacrifice it to the Lord your God.
verses.comment: Maintains the Levitical standard for unblemished sacrificial animals.

verses.text: You shall eat it within your gates; the unclean and the clean alike may eat it, as with the gazelle or the deer.
verses.comment: Animals with defects may be eaten by any, mirroring other wild game consumption.

verses.text: Only you shall not eat its blood; you shall pour it on the ground like water.
verses.comment: The prohibition on eating blood is consistently maintained through the Pentateuch.
